newsitem.title: USA: Broadcasters convention to meld media with computers.
newsitem.headline: Broadcasters convention to meld media with computers.

text.p: The lineup at this year's National Association of Broadcasters convention looks more like a computer industry confab than one devoted to the broadcast medium.
The convention long associated with television networks -- ABC, CBS, NBC, and Fox -- now draws the likes of International Business Machines Corp., Compaq Computer Corp. and Microsoft Corp.
The melding of the two industries is viewed as inevitable as digital technology transforms television.
"What you're going to see are a lot of computer companies becoming broadcasters," said Paul Saffo of the Institute for the Future, a Menlo Park, Calif.-based think tank. "Look at MSNBC."
MSNBC is a new cable network that is a joint venture of Microsoft and General Electric Co's NBC network, offering a "Generation X" style take on the news.

The NAB convention, which is taking place this week in Las Vegas, comes the week after Federal Communications Commission regulators approved rules giving broadcasters free license to provide high-definition digital television.
The FCC rules call for 30 percent of U.S. households to receive the broadcasts of at least three digital TV stations by May 1, 1999.
They may being receiving those stations sooner, however. Nearly two dozen stations in the top 10 markets have committed to being on the air within 18 months.
Digital technology is expected to allow broadcasters to squeeze as many as six channels on a single existing channel, or TV stations could offer a single high-definition channel.

In addition, digital TV is expected to hasten the convergence of TV and computer technologies. For example, sports fans would be able to watch a game and split their screens to receive the latest scores of other games over the Internet.
Those developments are a prime reason why the NAB has the look and feel of a computer convention.

"You will see the presence of the traditional computing companies in a market that has not been dominated by traditional computing companies," said John Gardner, manager for market development at IBM Video Enabled Solutions.

"Last year, there was a real sea change occurring with the movement from analog to digital and the blend of media and telecom with personal computing," he said. "The fundamental sea change is this covnerstion to digital from analog. This is a long term transformation, it started last year and it will increase because of the benefits of digital broadasting."

One of the highlights of the NAB event this year is a news conference to be held Monday by Intel Corp., Compaq and Microsoft where company executives are to discuss how the computer and broadcasting industries can work together on digital TV.
"The broadcasting industry in general is becoming increasingly aware of the opportunities PCs present," said Ron Whittier, senior vice president of Intel's content group.
Intel's elevated profile at the convention, he said, is in contrast to past years when the company offered only "token representation."
"You have to conclude this is the year of the PC at NAB," Whittier said.
